resources.string: Category based on the BMI result:

Individuals in this category have a BMI value indicating a severely low body weight, which may pose health risks. Adequate nutritional intake and medical attention may be necessary to address potential concerns related to under-nutrition.

This category includes individuals with a BMI suggesting moderate thinness. While not as severe as the "Severe Thinness" category, attention to proper nutrition and overall health is still crucial to prevent further weight loss.

Individuals in this category have a BMI indicating mild thinness. While they may not be severely underweight, it is advisable to monitor their weight and take steps to ensure they maintain a healthy balance through proper diet and lifestyle.
This is the ideal range for BMI, indicating a healthy weight relative to height. Individuals falling within this category generally have a lower risk of health issues associated with weight extremes.

Individuals in this category have a BMI suggesting excess weight, but they are not yet classified as obese. It is advisable for individuals in this range to adopt lifestyle changes such as healthier eating habits and increased physical activity to prevent further weight gain.

This category indicates the first level of obesity. Individuals with a BMI in this range may face an increased risk of obesity-related health issues, and interventions such as diet modification and regular exercise are typically recommended.

This represents a higher level of obesity, indicating a more significant excess of body weight. Health risks associated with obesity become more pronounced in this category, and medical supervision is often necessary to address potential complications.

This is the most severe level of obesity, indicating a substantial excess of body weight. Individuals in this category are at the highest risk of obesity-related health problems. Medical intervention, including lifestyle changes, dietary modifications, and possibly surgical options, may be considered to manage health risks associated with severe obesity.
